name: Bern
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bern's Old Town has 6 kilometers of arcaded walkways (Lauben) - covered shopping streets that are the longest in Europe. The city also has a peculiar tradition: the Zytglogge (clock tower) features a mechanical show with bears, jesters, and roosters performing 4 minutes before every hour since 1530.

hero_dishes.name: Berner Platte
hero_dishes.description: Massive platter of meats - sauerkraut, beans, potatoes, pork chops, bacon, pork ribs, beef tongue, and various sausages including Sch√ºblig
hero_dishes.origin_story: This hearty dish was created to feed hardworking farmers and soldiers. The name means 'Bernese platter' and it's designed for sharing (or one very hungry person). It showcases Bern's Germanic culinary traditions - pork in every form imaginable. Locals eat it in winter after skiing or hiking in the nearby Alps.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Altes Tramdepot brewery-restaurant with views of the Aare River, Kornhauskeller (historic granary cellar), or traditional Swiss restaurants in Old Town

hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally a Bernese farmer's breakfast, r√∂sti became Switzerland's national dish. The 'R√∂stigraben' (r√∂sti ditch) metaphorically divides German-speaking Switzerland (which loves r√∂sti) from French-speaking regions. Getting the crust perfectly crispy while keeping the inside tender is an art. Bern locals eat it as a side dish or main course.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Schwellenm√§tteli restaurant on the Aare River, Kornhauskeller, or any traditional Bernese restaurant

hero_dishes.name: Meringue with Whipped Cream (Meringu√©s)
hero_dishes.description: Large, crispy meringues served with double cream - simple, sweet, and rich
hero_dishes.origin_story: The village of Meiringen near Bern claims to have invented meringue in the 17th century (disputed by French). Regardless, Bern embraced it. The Swiss version uses generous amounts of double cream - not subtle. Locals order it as dessert after heavy meals, somehow finding room.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Confiserie Tschirren (historic pastry shop since 1919), cafes in Old Town, or Hotel Bellevue Palace

hero_dishes.name: Fondue Moiti√©-Moiti√©
hero_dishes.description: Swiss cheese fondue made with equal parts Gruy√®re and Vacherin Fribourgeois, white wine, and kirsch - served bubbling in a pot with bread cubes for dipping
hero_dishes.origin_story: While fondue is pan-Swiss, Bern's location between German and French Switzerland means they perfected the moiti√©-moiti√© (half-and-half) blend. The wine and kirsch keep the cheese smooth. Swiss rules: if you drop your bread in the pot, you buy the next round of wine. Never drink water with fondue - locals insist wine or schnapps prevents the cheese from solidifying in your stomach.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Du Nord restaurant, Kornhauskeller, or traditional Swiss restaurants especially in winter

signature_drinks.name: Rivella
signature_drinks.description: Swiss soft drink made from milk whey - slightly sweet, slightly fizzy, uniquely Swiss
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Rivella is Switzerland's national soft drink, invented in 1952. It's made from lactose-free milk whey, giving it a unique taste foreigners find strange but Swiss love. Bern locals drink it with meals, especially with rich foods like fondue or raclette. The red label is original flavor; blue is low-calorie.

signature_drinks.name: Kirsch (Cherry Brandy)
signature_drinks.description: Clear cherry brandy - strong, aromatic, traditional digestif
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Kirsch is essential in fondue (keeps cheese from solidifying) and drunk as digestif after heavy meals. Swiss cherry orchards produce the fruit. Locals in Bern sip it neat from small glasses after Berner Platte or fondue. It's warming, potent (40%+ alcohol), and helps digest mountains of cheese and pork.
